analytic.title: Design and implementation of a simple dynamical 4-D chaotic circuit with applications in image encryption Journal Pre-proof Design and implementation of a simple dynamical 4-D chaotic circuit with applications in image encryption

div.p: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The quest for simple chaotic circuits has been an interesting research undertaking for almost four decades [1]. This interest is mainly attributed to promising applications of such networks in different domains in science and engineering, such as cryptography [2], secure communication [3], robotics [4], random generator implementation [5], etc. Nevertheless, to date, only a few simple autonomous and non-autonomous chaotic circuits have been designed and implemented [6,7,8]. For instance, in [6], Chua explored combining a Capacitor-Inductor-Capacitor (CLC) network with a nonlinear negative resistor to propose an empirical, yet simple chaotic circuit. Since then, largely due to its simplicity, Chua's circuit has been extensively modified and reconfigured for many applications [9]. Examples of these modifications include the onediode Chua circuit [6], the n-scroll Chua circuit [8], the CMOS IC nonlinear resistor for Chua circuit [7],

Email address: amiliyasuz@gmail.com (Abdullah M. Iliyasu) etc. Inspired by the idea of a simple chaotic circuit, Elwakil et al. proposed a chaotic circuit based on a current feedback that is considered suitable for high frequency operations [10]. Moreover, using computer simulations, Murali et al. [11] demonstrated the occurrence of chaos in a sinusoidally propelled second-order circuit composed of one Chua diode and three linear components. Similarly, using a junction field effect transistor, Tchitnga et al. reported a five-component autonomous jerky chaotic circuit in [12]. While all the networks highlighted above manifest simplicity, they do not present extensive analysis in terms of multiple coexisting attractors, antimonotonicity, transient chaos, etc. as rigourously undertaken in this study and reported in recent studies on chaotic systems [13,14].

Meanwhile, [15]reported a fourth-circuit element made up of two nonlinear components with variable memristance (aka a memristor) that can memorise the amount of electric charge flowing through it. Considering its unavailability, commercial memristors are essentially emulators that model expected current-voltage (I-V) characteristics, including cubic nonlinearity [16], non-smooth piecewise linearity [17], smooth piecewise linearity [18], and HewlettPackard (HP) memristor model [19]. The intrinsic nonlinearity of memristors has been used to design new chaotic circuit models by substituting nonlinear components in traditional chaotic circuit models with memristor emulators. Even though most of these memristive systems [18] have very rich dynamic behaviours they are characterised by a relatively complex electronic circuit.

To ensure that dynamic characteristics are suffused into our network, in this study, we remodel and simplify the circuit network in [20] to realise an RLCC-diode Opamp chaotic circuit. Additionally, unlike previous efforts that employed three-dimensional chaotic circuits [20], which exhibit the unusual likelihood of using four distinct non-static attractors influenced by choice of initial states, to induce chaotic properties, our atypical 4-D chaotic circuit is built on a linear oscillator and a voltage controlled memristor (hybrid diode). Consequently, the memristor is the central component responsible for the complicated behaviour observed in our model. To further elucidate the difference between our circuit and other available ones, a comparative analysis of some memristive chaotic circuits with reference to dynamic complexity and the number of electronic components is provided in Table 1. Furthermore, we exploit the highlighted characteriscics of our model to implement an efficient image encryption protocol.
Table 1: Comparative analysis of some memristive chaotic circuits with reference to complexity dynamics.

div.head: Method
div.p: Number of components Number of coexisting attractors Proposed 6 2, 4, 6 Ref. [18] 6 2 Ref. [20] 7 2, 4 Ref. [21] 10 2, 4
To summarise, among others, the main objectives of our study include:
• Provide an in-depth analysis of chaos induction circuit dynamics through bifurcation diagrams, Lyapunov spectrum plots, phase traces as well as equilibrium and stability.
• Identify the regions in the space of parameters that the circuits display properties of coexisting attractors.
• Undertake extensive experimental measurements to evaluate the proposed network using standard tests.
• Deploy the proposed network in construction of chaotic circuits with competent S-Box parameters and generate PRNG sequences for efficient encryption of grayscale and colour images.

The remainder of the paper covers our remodelling of the Resistor-Inductor-Capacitor-Diode (RLCD) Opamp-based circuit in [20], which is built on a linear oscillator and a voltage controlled memristor (hybrid diode), and its use to construct our new 4-D chaotic circuit for chaos induction. This entails provision of detailed descriptions of the electronic model for the oscillator and development of a proper mathematical system to study the numerical dynamics as well as fixed points and stabilities of the circuit. All these are presented in Sec. 2. Following that, we present a two-fold analysis of our proposed circuit network. First, an extensive numerical analysis based on the Lyapunov spectrum and bifurcation diagrams are presented and discussed in Sec. 3. Second, the evaluation of the oscillator is undertaken via laboratory experiments on our circuit(built on a breadboard). These results are presented in Sec. 4. The proposed circuit network is refined and used to construct S-Box mechanisms and generate PRNG sequences that form the core components of our image encryption protocol whose design and implementation are presented and discussed in Sec. 5. Finally, in Sec. 6, we present an extensive validation of our proposed encryption protocol by comparing its performance alongside established methods that are in the literature.

div.head: State equations and system description
div.p: The circuit considered in this study (presented in Fig. 1a) is a reconfiguration of the single Opamp-based autonomous LC chaotic circuit previously analysed in [20]. This circuit comprises of a simple linear oscillator and hybrid diode-bridge (presented in Fig. 1b) for chaos induction. Four dynamical elements are used to construct the circuit including capacitors C 1 , C 2 , C 0 and an inductor L; thus, due to the extra memory component produced via the hybrid diode circuit, the network is said to have an order of four. Using the Kirchhoff voltage law and the exponential properties of the pair of antiparallel diodes using a first-order parallel RC filter, it is trivial that the circuit (in Fig. 1) is controlled by the subsequent set of first-order non-linear differential equations as defined in (1).
div.formula:            C 1 dv C1 dt = -v C2 R C 2 dv C2 dt = v C2 R + i L + 2I s sinh( v C1 -v C2 -v C0 V ref ) L di L dt = v C1 -v C2 C 0 dv C0 dt = 2I s cosh( v C1 -v C2 -v C0 V ref ) -v C0 R0 )(1)
div.p: To obtain numerical solutions for the circuit, it important to anticipate changes in parameters and variables as inferred in (2).
div.formula: x 1 = v C1 /V ref , x 2 = v C2 /V ref , x 1 = ρi L /V ref , x 4 = v C0 /V ref , t = τ √ LC 2 , ρ = L/C 2 , a = ρ/R , b = C 2 /C 1 , c = C 2 /C 0 , a 0 = ρ/R 0(2)
div.p: Therefore, the circuit's model can be defined by a set of 4-D ordinary differential equation (ODE) as follows:

Here, it is important to note that all variables are real-valued and can be visualised via a standard oscilloscope during laboratory colorredimplementation. Moreover, using the mathematical framework in (2) and subsequent discussions in the sequel, characteristics of five parameters can be deduced. However, in this study, the parameter a i.e. related to resistor R) will be regarded as the central bifurcation control parameter.

div.head: Fixed points and stabilities
div.p: We investigated the stability points of the model in (3) as solutions to the following algebraic equations:

The unique point of ordinary equilibrium is obtained at the origin O(0, 0, 0, 0). By linearising (i.e. using (3)) that equilibrium point (origin point), the resulting 4 × 4 Jacobian matrix can be defined as:
The eigenvalues correlated with this matrix are obtained by solving the resulting particular equation:
where:
div.formula:                a 4 = 1 a 3 = a 0 c + a + cε + ε a 2 = aa 0 c + 1 + acε + a 0 cε + abε a 1 = a 0 c + ab + a 0 abcε + cε a 0 = a 0 abc + abcε(7)
div.p: Referring to the Routh-Hurwitz [22] stability criteria, we find that the single equilibrium is stable when b ≤ b c = 1. As a result, Hopf bifurcation conditions were calculated as follows:
div.formula: b c = 1, ω 2 Hopf = a 0 c + ab + a 0 abcε + cε a 0 c + a + cε + ε . (8a
Re dλ db b=bc = - 1 2 2a(a 2 0 c 2 + a 0 ac + 1) (a + a 0 c) 2 + (aa 0 c + 1) 2 = 0. (8b
div.p: The equation in (8a) gives the frequency of the steady oscillations and the crucial value of the control parameter b, which corresponds to the system's Hopf bifurcation. From Eq. (8b), it is easily inferred that the transversal condition is always satisfied. To complete the study of the local stability of the circuit modeled by the system in (3), we present in Table 2 the eigenvalues of the equation. The table is obtained using the Newton-Raphson technique over changing values of b in the range 0.1 ≤ b ≤ 10 while the remaining parameters are maintained at a = 1, c = 1, a 0 = 4, ε= 4.0989 × 10 -5 .

div.head: Rich dynamical properties of proposed system
div.p: We assign default parameters b = 200; c = 1; a 0 = 4, ε= 4.0989 × 10 -5 . When parameter a is tuned up or down in the range 1 ≤ a ≤ 13, the bifurcation diagram is plotted as the local maximum of x 1 (τ ) versus parameter a (see Fig. 2a). Next, using Wolf's algorithm [23], the four Lyapunov exponents are calculated as outlined in Fig. 2b and, from these diagrams, it can be deduced that the proposed circuit can dynamically display properties of periodic attractors as well as single and double band chaotic attractors.

Further, the traditional period-doubling paths to chaos with the symmetry curing trauma are illustrated in Fig. 3. Consequently, the system in (2) exhibits the striking phenomenon of remerging Feigenbaum trees. That entails the concurrent production and annihilation of cyclic orbits [24]. This behaviour is demonstrated by varying a parameter for certain discrete values of another parameter of the same system. For instance, the bifurcation diagrams exposing local maximum of the state variable x 1 of the attractor in Poincaré crosssection relative to the control parameter a that are plotted in Fig. 4 for several discrete values of parameter b. The remaining system parameters are fixed at c = 1, a 0 = 4 , ε= 4.0989 × 10 -5 .

To illustrate the complex dynamical behaviour of the system in (3), we further display, in Fig. 5, the Lapunov exponent stability diagram. This diagram shows various characteristics depending on the degree of stability. Since it is manifest that Lapunov's indicators cannot distinguish between different phases of oscillations, then this graph has practical importance since it gives a general picture of the dynamics under the influence of system parameters. The system dynamics are accentuated by plotting different dynamical performances for the bifurcation parameters b and a (see Fig. 6). Here, the chaotic area is highlighted in yellow whereas the periodic region is demarcated in red. Meanwhile, the remaining system parameters used are maintained at c = 1, a 0 = 4 , ε= 4.0989 × 10 -5 .

It is important to note that the state variable x 3 appears just once in the second equation of the system in (3). Thus, we can control the state variable x 3 by replacing it with x 3 + m and so the system in (3) can be rewritten as:

By tuning m for a given set of parameters, any attractor can be shifted (see Fig. 7) as well as its basin of attraction without altering the system's solution. This dynamic parameter, called offset-boosting, has been used (in [25]) to determine coexisting attractors in chaotic dynamical systems. Therefore, it is interesting to reveal its presence as a signature of multistability in a given system.

Metastable chaos is also investigated in systems with trajectories starting from initial states chosen at random and approaching a fixed point or periodic orbit [15]. Prior to arriving at the ultimate state, these trajectories may approach a chaotic saddle and remain in its vicinity for a limited time. It is noteworthy that the phenomenon of unstable chaos is hardly noticed in actual experimental laboratory measurements because of its relatively short life. These conclusions have been reported previously in studies on dynamical systems such as [26,27]. A transient is obtained from the system in (3) when parameters are fixed at a = 3.747, b = 600 , c = 1 , a 0 = 1.5, ε = 2.3665 × 10 -5 and the system is solved using the initial values (x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0), x 4 (0), ) ≡ (1.2, 0, 0, 0). Before reaching the final state, transient chaotic attractor in Fig. 8b(i) and the corresponding frequency spectra in Fig. 8b(ii) are observed. But when the solution is prolonged, a cyclic orbit in the steady-state in and the corresponding frequency spectrum are observed in Fig. 8a (i) and (ii), respectively.

div.head: Coexisting bifurcations and Multistability analysis
div.p: Multistability of a system means that for a set of fixed system parameters, it is sensitive to its primary states and can display multiple coexisting attractors, which has proven to be an exciting research undertaking [28,21]. In this study, coexisting bifurcation diagrams are used to demonstrate the striking dynamics. These diagrams are produced via downward and upward switching of a control parameter. A demonstration of the implied multistability is shown in Fig. 9 where the local maximum of the variable x 1 is computed and plotted relative to the control parameter a. Table 3 presents results emanating from this strategy.

The plot in Fig. 9 presents regions whose systems display coexistence comprising of four distinct attractors as presented in Fig. 10 and Fig. 11. Initial parameters and conditions used in Fig. 9 are presented in Table 4 where the red (or green) diagram is obtained by increasing (or decreasing) the control parameter a from 3 to 5 (or from 3 to 1). Meanwhile, the area demarcated in blue is realised by increasing the control parameter a from 1 to 5 with the initial parameters preset at (x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0), x 4 (0)) ≡ (0.5333, 0, 0, 0). Similarly, the system in (3) is solved by varying parameter a in the range 1 ≤ a ≤ 5 with the bifurcation diagram plotted in Fig. 12 (see Table 3 for more details). The red (or blue) diagram is realised by increasing (or decreasing) the control parameter a from 1 to 5 (or from 5 to 1) while the green (or magenta) area is obtained by increasing (or decreasing) the control parameter a from 2.48 to 5 (or decreasing from 5 to 2.48) with the initial parameters preset at (x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0), x 4 (0)) ≡ (0.4, 0, 0, 0). The coexisting bifurcation diagrams (in Fig. 12) show that depending solely on the variation in initial conditions, the system experiences up to six disconnected attractors. Sample results are presented in Figs. 13 and14 where four or six varied attractors synchronise in phase space respectively. It is important to clarify that in [20] the striking dynamics were reported with just four disconnected symmetric attractors. Therefore, based on the above outcomes it can be concluded that the present study provides useful insights for understanding the non-linear dynamics of this kind of the oscillator. However, this phenomena is similarly reported in other nonlinear dynamic systems such as [28,21]. Nevertheless, while the multiplicity of attractors is a supplementary but useful kind of behaviour that is used in real-world applications, such as chaos-based cryptographic applications [3], its behaviour is generally undesirable. Thus, tight control is necessary. Consequently, since this application does not in any way benefit our proposed implementation, its analysis is considered outside the scope of our study. Notwithstanding, interested readers are referred to [13] where interesting perspectives can be obtained.

div.head: Practical implementation of proposed circuit
div.p: Figure 15 presents the configuration used in the laboratory implementation of our proposed circuit network whose diagram was presented earlier in Fig. 1. The circuit for our laboratory implementation was built on a breadboard using components whose values are summarized in Table 5. By slowly tuning the control potentiometer, the experimental stage traces are recorded using the XY mode of a dual-trace oscilloscope. The experimental memristive circuit can also exhibit the classical period-doubling access to chaos. For R = 750Ω, a limit cycle of 1 period is observed. When R decreases gradually, the full bifurcation sequence is observed (see Fig. 16). This becomes apparent from the traces of the experimental phase in Fig. 17, which displays the behaviour of the circuit proposed in this study.

Using component values C 1 = 10nF, C 2 = 6µF, C 0 = 6µF, L = 285mH R 0 = 174.4Ω and control resistor R = 225Ω, coexisting attractors have also been investigated in the experimental circuit. When the voltage is switched on and off, either a limited cycle or a single band chaotic attractor is observed. The experimental results for the existence of our coexisting attractors is presented in Fig. 18. With reference to the numerical phase trace, we can see that the experimental circuit exhibits the expected behaviour. However, slight differences between numerical and experimental results can be observed. These differences are partly attributed to the accuracy of electronic components used as well as simplifications and assumptions employed in modelling the circuit.

div.head: S-box Construction and PRNG Generation
div.p: Designing secure and powerful substitution boxes (S-boxes) for efficient cryptosystems attracts widespread attention from cryptographers, computers scientists and electrical engineers. Moreover, S-box construction plays an essential part in nonlinear transformations, which are the fulcrum of confusion and diffusion analysis for assessing well-designed ciphers. Therefore, designing S-boxes based on secure mechanisms plays an important part in modern cryptographic tasks. Consequently, motivated by the dynamical behaviours it has, in this study, we consider deploying our proposed 4-D chaotic circuit network to construct S-boxes based on chaotic sequences generated by the coexisting attractors, which together with a PRNG generator form the core units of our proposed image encryption protocol.

div.head: S-box construction
div.p: We start by presenting an outline of the S-box construction, which requires an adjustment to our 4-D chaotic system as presented in (10).
div.formula:          x i+1 = (-aby i ) mod 1 y i+1 = (-ay i + z i + sinh(x i -y i -w i )) mod 1 z i+1 = (x i -y i ) mod 1 w i+1 = (c( sinh(x i -y i -w i ) -a 0 w i )) mod 1(10)
div.p: Next, we outline the S-box construction mechanism via the five steps described in the sequel.

1. Select initial seeds for x 0 , y 0 , z 0 , and w 0 as well as a values for the control parameters a, b, c, a 0 and , to iterate the new 4-D chaotic system over the 256 times required to generate four sequences
div.formula: { X i }, { Y i },{ Z i } and { W i }.
div.p: 2. Convert the sequence { W i } (in step 1) into integer values using Eq. ( 11)
div.formula: SW i = |f ix(W i )×10 8 |mod 3(11)
div.p: 3. Generate sequence {Q i } from the remaining sequences {X i }, {Y i }, and { Z i } as defined in ( 12) using ( 11) 4. Arrange elements of Q in ascending order to form a sequence A. 5. Construct S-box by forging the sequence S which contains the index of each element of Q in A.
div.formula: Q i =      X i if SW i = 0 Y i if SW i = 1 Z i if SW i = 2(12)

div.head: PRNG generator
div.p: Pseudo-random number generation (PRNG) plays a fundamental role in designing powerful cryptographic schemes. The key feature of PRNG is its provision of lengthy streams of numbers embedded with features that enhance randomness [5]. PRNG has a vital impact on the robustness of signals emanating from cryptographic applications and in ensuring that such signals cannot be violated, tampered with, or the secret information regenerated. The standard approach to designing PRNG generators involves the use of chaos maps. Therefore, in this study, we exploit the proven properties of our proposed 4-D chaotic system to generate four PRNG sequences. This is accomplished in the steps enumerated below:

1. Select initial seeds for x 0 , y 0 , z 0 , and w 0 as well as values for the control parameters a, b, c, a 0 and ε, to iterate the new 4-D chaotic system over N times required to generate four sequences {X i }, {Y i }, {Z i } and {W i }. 2. Convert the sequences {X i }, {Y i }, {Z i } and {W i } into integer entries of PRNG sequences as defined

div.head: Performance of S-box and PRNG mechanisms
div.p: To examine the performance of the S-box and PRNG mechanisms, a workstation equipped with Intel core TM i5-2450M and 6 GB RAM and a preinstalled MATLAB R2016b software is used. The initial states to iterate the new 4-D chaotic system are set as x 0 = 0.59, y 0 =0.87, z 0 =0.15,w 0 =0.8922, a= 4.368, b= 200, c= 1, a 0 =4, ε =4.0989 ×10 -5 .

The resulting S-box entries is presented in Table 6, while a comparison of constructed S-box alongside recent schemes in terms of linear approximation probabilities (LP), nonlinearity, bit independence (BIC), as well strict avalanche characteristics (SAC) is presented in Table 7.

Similarly, to establish the effectiveness of PRNG mechanism, we assessed the randomness property of the resulting sequences as stipulated via NIST SP 800-22 tests, which are considered as the industry standard. These tests consist of 15 examinations that are performed on each generated sequence with 10 6 bits length and, as presented in Table 8, all our generated sequences passed tests that were administered.

div.head: Chaos-based image encryption protocol
div.p: The applications of chaotic systems in image encryption is not new, including many approaches employing one-dimensional or higher dimensional chaotic systems to produce a sequence of random numbers for construction of a cipher image that have been proposed [32,33,34]. However, most of these schemes are vulnerable to various attacks due to their marginal key-space. In contrast, based on its large key-space and as demonstrated via its use in constructing S-boxes and generating PRNG sequences, in this section, we present an image encryption protocol that utilises the chaotic capabilities of our proposed 4D symmetric hybrid RLCC diode Opamp circuit which was discussed in earlier sections. In this chaotic image encryption scheme (whose outline is presented in Fig. 19), each element of the original image is substituted with elements of the S-box following which a bitwise XOR operation is performed on the substituted image and PRNG generated sequences.

div.head: Encryption algorithm
div.p: Figure 19 presents the outline of our proposed encryption protocol, which comprises of an encryption and decryption procedure. However, our study is just focused on the encryption process which is discussed and validated in the remainder of this section.
The encryption procedure is executed in the five steps enumerated below.

1. Select initial seeds for x 0 , y 0 , z 0 , and w 0 and the control parameters a, b, c, a 0 and , for constructing the S-box and PRNG sequences {X i }, {Y i },{Z i } and {W i } each with dimension h×w, which is the size of the input image (O). 2. Substitute each pixel in image O with its corresponding element in S-box to construct substituted image S. Table 5: Component values used in the experimental analysis implemented via circuit setup in Fig. 13 as reported in the text 3. Convert the sequences {X i }, {Y i }, {Z i } and {W i } into integer entries as defined in ( 14)
div.formula: Component Values Reference Type R 0 Resistance 170Ω R 1 Resistance 95Ω C 0 Capacitance 2µF C 1 Capacitance 10ηF C 2 Capacitance 2µF L Inductance L = 285mH D 1 , D 1 Diodes 1N 4148 U Operational Amplifier T L082
SX i = |f ix(X i ) × 10 8 |mod 256 SY i = |f ix(Y i ) × 10 8 |mod 256 SZ i = |f ix(Z i ) × 10 8 |mod 256 SW i = |f ix(W i ) × 10 8 |mod 3 (14)
div.p: 4. For greyscale images we proceed as presented in step (a); otherwise, for colour images, we go to step (a) Generate sequence K as defined in ( 15)
div.formula: K i =      SX i if SW i = 0 SY i if SW i = 1 SZ i if SW i = 2 (15)
div.p: (b) Generate sequence K as defined in ( 16)
div.formula: K(i, :) =      [SX i , SY i , SZ i ] if SW i = 0 [SY i , SZ i , SX i ] if SW i = 1 [SZ i , SX i , SY i ] if SW i = 2

div.head: Performance analysis
div.p: To establish the efficiency of our proposed image encryption protocol, we simulated its implementation using a dataset comprising of three gray-scale images (labelled GImg01, GImg02 and GImg03 as presented in Fig. 20(a-c)) and three colour images (labelled CImg01, CImg02 and CImg03 as presented in Fig. 20(g-i)) each of 512 × 512 dimension. The initial values for iterating the proposed 4-D chaotic system are set at x 0 = 0.59, y 0 =0.87, z 0 =0.15,w 0 =0.8922, a= 4.368, b= 200, c= 1, a 0 =4, ε =4.0989 ×10 -5 .
All experiments reported were executed using a workstation equipped with Intel core TM i5-2450M and 6 GB RAM and a preinstalled MATLAB R2016b software.

div.head: Time complexity
div.p: Time complexity is a significant tool used to evaluate the performance of an image encryption algorithm. It measures the actual time required to encrypt one image. Our proposed image encryption algorithm utilizes S-box construction as well as PRNG sequence generation both of which are impacted by the dimension of the image. Therefore, we measure time complexity in terms of time elapsed in each stage of implementing the proposed technique, i.e. time for constructing S-box, generating PRNG sequences, and for encrypting the images. Table 9 presents the execution time for the proposed mechanism for different size of images. Based on the total time in Table 9, we present a comparison between our execution time and those from other schemes in Table 10. Therefrom, we observe the impressive time complexity of our proposed method. [35] 0.0244 0.0949 0.4010 1.9857 Ref. [36] 0.0774 0.1179 0.2744 0.7890 Ref. [37] 0.0902 0.3440 1.3357 5.3223 Ref. [38] 0.0579 0.2224 0.9731 3.9377 Ref. [39] 0.1531 0.6347 2.4913 9.9185 There are several tools to measure the relationship between two images, such as correlation coefficient of adjacent pixels Cor ab . Pristine, i.e. unenciphered, images have Cor ab values close to unity (i.e. 1) in each direction, whereas well encrypted images have values close to zero. To compute Cor ab for the encrypted and original images in each direction, we randomly selected 10 4 pairs of neighboring pixels and computed their correlation coefficient using (17).

div.head: Statistical analysis • Correlation of adjacent pixels
div.formula: (a) GImg01 (b) GImg02 (c) GImg03 (d) Enc-GImg01 (e) Enc-GImg02 (f) Enc-GImg03 (g) CImg01 (h) CImg02 (i) CImg03 (j) Enc-CImg01 (k) Enc-CImg02 (l) Enc-CImg03
Cor ab = D i=1 (a i -ā) b i -b D i=1 (a i -ā) 2 D i=1 b i -b 2(17)
div.p: where a i , b i refers to the values of adjacent pixels and D is the sum of adjacent pixel pairs along each direction. Tables 11 and12 present the values of Cor ab for greyscale and colour images and their respective encrypted versions. From the tables, we see that Cor ab values for the encrypted images are close to 0. In order to demonstrate the efficiency of the presented image encryption mechanism in terms of correlation coefficients, in Table 13, we provide the comparisons of its average values of correlation coefficients alongside various image encryption methods. Further, the distribution of two neighbouring pixels in each direction for GImg01 image is presented in Fig. 21 and that for the 3 channels of the CImg01 colour image are presented in Figs. 22, 23 and 24. The absence or inability to decipher any meaningful information from the results in Tables 11,12, and 13 as well as Figs. 21, 22, 23 and 24 are evidence of the efficiency of our proposed encryption protocol.

• Pixels change rate Two metrics that are widely used in evaluating the impact of changes in the pixel values that constitute a pristine image relative to its corresponding encrypted version are Unified Average Changing Intensity (UACI) and Number of Pixels Change Rate (NPCR), which are defined in Eqs. [44] 0.0010 0.0007 0.0004 Ref. [45] -0.0061 -0.0001 -0.0002 Ref. [46] -0.0067 0.0053 -0.0022 Ref. [47] 0.0061 0.0036 0.0067 Ref. [48] -0.0067 -0.0021 -0.0027
div.formula: N P CR = x,y D(x,y) M × 100% , D(x, y) = 0 if A(x, y) = B(x, y) 1 if A(x, y) = B(x, y)(18)
div.p: where M is the sum of pixels in the image. Implementation of our proposed protocol produces the NPCR values as well UACI values in Table 14, wherein average values of 99.61% and 33.52%, are reported for test images used in the experiments. As presented in Table 15, these results attest to the sensitivity of the proposed technique to small changes in the composition of pristine images. This performance is further enunciated via comparisons between our average values and those obtained from other methods (in Table 15).

div.head: • Histogram analysis
div.p: Histogram analysis is another tool employed to assess the performance of the encryption mechanism, which provides the distribution of pixel values in the image. As an indication of its ability to offer effective resistance against statistical attacks, a well-designed image encryption protocol should have uniform histograms for different encrypted images. Figures 25 and26 present histograms of several input images which are distinct from each other whereas the histograms of their ciphered versions are identical to each other. To validate the histogram analysis for our cipher images we perform chi-square test (χ 2 ), which, for an 8-bit greyscale image, is computed via Eq. (20).

where f v is the frequency of the pixel value v (v =0,1,2,...,255), d = (h×w)/256, for a h by w dimension image. A histogram is categorised as uniformly distributed if for a significant level 0.05 (χ 2 0.05 (255) = 293.24783) the χ 2 test is less than χ 2 0.05 (255). Table 16 presents outcomes of the χ 2 test for the greyscale images in our experimental dataset. As highlighted earlier, this property indicates the uniform distribution of the histograms of the reported encrypted images. Similarly, the results of the χ 2 test for the colour images in our experimental dataset are presented in Table 17. Furthermore, to establish that this performance is in conformity with standard approaches, we compared the average results reported in Table 16 alongside those from other schemes that have been reported in the literature. The outcomes presented in Table 18 support the conclusion that our 4-D chaotic circuit approach to image encryption produces encrypted images with uniformly distributed histograms, which is considered essential for resisting histogram analysis attacks.

div.head: • Information entropy
div.p: Global entropy is another veritable tool used to assess the efficiency of image encryption algorithms. It is a statistical measure of the distribution of pixel values for each level in the image and it can be expressed

where p(x i ) is the probability of x i and since gray-scale images have 2 8 possible values then the ideal entropy value should be close to 8-bit. However, it has been argued that global entropy fails to estimate the real randomness of cipher images. Therefore, in [49] Wu et al. presented in a modified entropy measure to calculate the accurate randomness of an image named local entropy. The local entropy can be measured by calculating the mean of global Shannon entropies over all the non-overlapping blocks in the image, where each block has 1936 pixels [49]. Table 19 presents the global and local entropy values for the experimental dataset employed to validate our proposed encryption procedure. Furthermore, in Table 20, we provide comparisons of average global and local entropy for our proposed method alongside those from different image encryption methods. Outcomes from both tables (i.e. Table 19 and Table 20) validate the performance of our proposed approach in terms of expected results and in comparison with results from established schemes in [40,41,42]. 7.9993 7.9024 Ref. [41] 7.9992 7.9023 Ref. [42] 7.9972 7.9025

div.head: Key sensitivity analysis
div.p: To test sensitivity of keys emanating from our proposed image encryption protocol, we executed the decryption process on the encrypted versions of the GImg01 and CImg01 images using several keys as well as small changes in key parameters. These results are presented in Fig. 27, wherefrom it can be deduced that slight changes in one of the key parameters resulted in complete distortions to the decrypted image; hence, validating the high sensitivity our proposed technique to even the slightest alterations in initial key parameters.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: In this study, a 4-D chaotic circuit is designed by replacing one diode of an RLCC-diode Opamp with a memristive hybrid diode circuit. Our simple yet highly dimensional chaotic circuit is imbued with complex behaviours as manifest in its stability in terms of equilibrium point and the dynamical behaviour, which are assessed numerically and experimentally using appropriate variations in circuit parameters. The results indicate that the circuit has only one unstable equilibrium point and it exhibits complex nonlinear characteristics such as multiple coexisting attractors, transient chaos and antimonotonicity. Unlike available simple chaotic circuits, we deployed extensive numerical and experimental approaches to assess circuit parameter space utilisation, including coexistence of six and four disconnected chaotic attractors. Furthermore, we explored and implemented the use of chaotic sequences of our proposed coexisting attractors and its use to construct S-boxes and and generate PRNG sequences that produced an efficient image encryption algorithm which was extensively validated using standard encryption metrics. The results indicate that the proposed encryption algorithm performs within nominal standards and outperforms recent techniques in terms of global and local information entropy, correlation coefficients, NPCR and UACI, distribution of pixel values in the encrypted images, time complexity and sensitivity to initial key parameters. These outcomes suggest that our proposed chaotic encryption mechanism could serve as a water-tight protocol to safeguard greyscale and colour images from illicit tampering.

figure.head: Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 1: (a) Circuit network for implementation of proposed RLCC chaotic oscillator based on a hybrid diode, and (b) hybrid diode symbol and its corresponding discrete implementation (Parameter values for electronic components used in experimental implementation of the same network are presented later in Table5).

figure.head: Figure 2 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 2: Bifurcation diagrams showing in (a) local maximum of the axis x 1 contra a and the Lyapunov spectra and in (b) an outline in the range 1 ≤ a ≤ 13 for b = 200; c = 1; a 0 = 4; ε= 4.0989 × 10 -5 . Here, chaos has positively-valued Lyapunov exponents (λ 1 > 0) whereas standard dynamics are negatively-valued (λ 1 < 0) .

figure.head: Figure 3 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 3: Two-dimensional diagrams of attractors for periods that double the path to chaos in the proposed system for changing parameter a with initial values as (±1, 0, 0,0): (a) when symmetric Period-1 for a = 0.5, (b) when Period-1 for a = 9.15,(c) when Period-2 for a = 1.45,(d) when single-band for a = 1.6,(e) when double-band for a = 5, (f) when single-band for a = 9.15,(g) when Period-2 for a = 11,(h) when Period-1 for a = 13.

figure.head: Figure 4 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 4: Bifurcation diagrams displaying the local maximum of x 1 of the attractor in Poincaré cross-section according to the control parameter of remerging Feigenbaum tree.

figure.head: Figure 5 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 5: Lyapunov stability diagram in (a, c), (b, c), (a, b) scales illustrating the regions of periodic oscillations (i.e. λmax ≤ 0) and the regions of chaotic dynamics (i.e. λmax > 0).

figure.head: Figure 6 :

figure.head: Figure 7 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 7: Results of simultaneous variation in shift of a chaotic attractor with control parameter m =-2 (red), m = 0 (blue) and m = 2 (green). (a) in the x1-x2 plane, (b) in the x1-x3 plane, and (c) in the x3-x4 plane.

figure.head: Figure 8 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 8: Illustration of metastable chaos for constant system parameters, i.e. a = 3.747, b = 600 , c = 1 , a 0 = 1.5, ε = 2.3665 × 10 -5 . a(i) presents periodic orbit in the steady state while a(ii) presents its related frequency spectrum; similarly, b(i) presents transient chaotic attractor whereas b(ii) presents its related frequency spectrum. Initial conditions are set at (x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0), x 4 (0), ) ≡ (1.2, 0, 0, 0) throughout.
